item.title: xv6 Chapter 2: Operating System Organization
item.description:
After a bit of an unexpected break, I have been able to get back to my operating systems study. So, let’s take a look at some of the key ideas in chapter 2 of the xv6 book!

Operating System Organization Link to heading

In the introduction to the chapter, the authors claim:

[A]n operating system must fulfill three requirements: multiplexing, isolation, and interaction.

Multiplexing refers to multiple programs being able to run on the computer, ideally without any one program hogging time or resources. Isolation means that the operating system must protect programs from one another. And, interaction means that the OS must allow programs to communicate with each other in a safe manner.

item.title: xv6 Chapter 1: Operating System Interfaces
item.description: I’ve recently started an effort to learn more about operating systems, particularly Unix-like systems. Modern operating systems offer a lot of incredible capabilities for application programmers, and they can even provide unique ways of delivering applications. For example, containers are largely possible because of Linux capabilities such as namespaces and cgroups. However, I would like to spend some time digging into the foundations of operating systems so that I have a better framework with which to explore some of these unique, modern capabilities.
